The transfer and centrality

Jun 12, 2020

In this paper, I stated the following ``centrality conjecture’’: the element lifts to . Example 3.3.11 shows that this is true when and , i.e., is central. This is really easy to see: is precisely the image of . But this doesn’t have any hope of generalizing to higher .

Rather, one can give approach proving centrality as follows (I’m pretty sure I’ve explained this elsewhere on the blog, but might as well repeat it). Let me write for convenience. If is to have any hope of lifting to , then it must certainly lift to , where as the maximal torus.

The class was obtained by Thomifying the composite

The map in turn is the composite

This map is actually -equivariant, if we view as the unit sphere in equipped with the canonical -action, and as equipped with the conjugation action of . Upon Thomification, one can show that the map is -equivariant.

We now make the following simple observation. If is a -equivariant map, then lifts to if and only if factors through . In particular, lifts to if and only if it factors as . This homotopy quotient is not hard to determine, since : we have an equivalence

where there are factors in the product. In particular, lifts to if and only if there is a factorization

where the first map is the inclusion of the bottom cell.

If and , then , and so we need a map such that the composite with the inclusion detects . But this is easy: one just takes the composite

where the first map is the -transfer. I’m fairly confident that you can probably construct the factorization for general using a suitable transfer, but haven’t worked this out yet.
